did.unittitle: Benjamin Franklin Papers Part 5 -- Letters to Franklin
did.abstract:
This is part of the large inventory for the Benjamin Franklin Papers (Mss B F85). For complete information concerning this collection, please view the
Collection Description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of the schooner called the "Committee" from Boston; news of Count d'Estaing being in Georgia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the purchase and fitting out of two large ships, built at Amsterdam; believes with Franklin's aid, Capt. Jones's skill and his own assiduity that there is a fair prospect of their procuring a fleet for America; his disinterested devotion to that country; begs Franklin to take him by the hand and steer him through this difficulty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As Franklin has shown an interest in the advantages arising from the discovery of animal magnetism, hopes that he will satisfy himself of the genuineness of certain cures he has made; besides the cases that Franklin has already seen, has several others which he will show him on the following Wednesday, if he will dine with him on that day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for the return of M. Nairne's memoir on the apparatus designed for storing electricity. Impossible to procure another copy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of his barbarous treatment by the English during his captivity; unhappy situation of the unfortunate prisoners in Plymouth; afraid they will be obliged to enter the English service unless they are soon exchanged.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, I, 348.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to procure his exchange and release him from his present condition of slavery.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repeating his former request that he may be set at liberty and suffered to return to America.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Penet, D'Acosta frères and Cie. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing two letters just arrived from Philadelphia; one for Franklin and one for M. Le Ray de Chaumont.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General belief that Spain will acknowledge America's independence, with the result of establishing consulships in her different ports. Desires the position of Consul at Barcelona.
(In French.)
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know if Franklin will receive the Commander of the King's frigate "l'Oiscau"; he is anxious to consult with him on a matter of some interest.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News received of the arrival at Savannah of a detachment from Comte d'Estaing's fleet, who took and destroyed the British armed vessels on the coast and made prisoners of eight hundred soldiers at Beaufort.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of a certificate by Harmen Fleus, pilot, stating that on November 28th Vice Admiral Reynst ordered the ship "Alliance" to go to sea when wind and weather rendered it both dangerous and impossible then and since November 23d; orders from Admiral Reynst have exceeded both the intention and terms of the last Resolution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin reported to have claimed his descent from a notary of Pontoise named Dagneaux; is in a position to procure the genealogy of this family.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Mr. Thomas Ridout. Acknowledges his favor of June 20th by the Chevalier de la Luzerne. Reasons why he resigned his seat in Congress. Deplorable state of the public credit; heavy taxation recommended by Congress. Exorbitant price of all provisions; measures suggested by Congress to check this evil. Describes the army as consisting of 20,000 fine, hardy fellows, well disciplined, well armed, and pretty tolerably clothed, but not strong enough to drive the English out of New York. Sketches a plan of operation which he believes would result in bringing the war to a speedy issue.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a copy of the King's speech to Parliament. Will be pleased to receive Franklin's commands; ambitious to serve his country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the two commissions for the "Black Prince" and "Princess." Aid given to Mr. Wharton and Mr. de Chaumont in their mission. If Capt. Conyngham comes to Dunkirk will give him Franklin's letter and furnish him with the necessary funds. Sorry that Franklin has been troubled with complaints from some of the people of the "Black Prince"; gives an impartial opinion on the subject. Encloses two letters for Franklin from Jonathan Arnold, late lieutenant of the "Black Prince," who made his escape from prison with Capt. Conyngham.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A warm denial of the charges brought by William Power and his gang against their worthy friend, Mr. John Torris; his generous behavior to every individual of the crew of the "Black Prince."

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Jacques Rocquette, T.A. Elsevier, and Fréres Rocquette. Rotterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of August 6th concerning a first draft of the United States, drawn on Franklin for $30, and presented for payment; precautionary measures they have taken in case of forgery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to serve the American cause; must conceal his true name until he receives an answer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Vindicating himself of charges brought by certain prisoners, headed by one William Power, who first swore allegiance to the United States and now refuses to serve except under the English flag; Mr. Coffyn and all honest citizens know his probity and no one has just cause to complain of him for the armament of the "Black Prince."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard that Franklin intends taking a hotel in Paris, and consequently will need the services of a porter; recommends a man called Abbey.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congress having appointed him to a new mission in Europe, embarked on November 13th, but his vessel having sprung a formidable leak, was obliged to anchor at Ferrol. Is the bearer of despatches from Congress and some newspapers containing an account of the evacuation of Rhode Island by the enemy, and of the Comte d'Estaing's progress in Georgia. Hopes the "Confederacy" arrived safely with M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gé [de Rayneval] and Mr. Jay, who is appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to Spain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishing to know the value of a quantity of American paper money. Concerning the session of the "Assemblé publique de la Faculteé,"and the effort that will be made to reconcile them with the "Société Royale de Médecine." Report of Count d'Estaing's feats in Georgia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business with M. Mercier; sending paper money and receipts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Moses Grinnell's misfortunes; measures to help him recover the lost bills of exchange.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Doubtful whether Commodore Jones's squadron sailed or not.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Six Americans who escaped from Mill prison in England and who were arrested on suspicion on landing in France, petition Franklin to obtain their release.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Made his escape from an English prison only to be put in a French jail; begs to be released and enabled to return to his family in Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Difficulties in the way of obtaining the condemnation of the prize goods taken by the "Mifflin"; begs Franklin to obtain the necessary papers. Saw in an American paper an address to the people of Ireland, signed with Franklin's name; wishes to know if it is genuine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of Mr. George Phillips, who was taken prisoner by the French; desires a passport to enable him to return to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has a new invention, which is a great improvement on the usual musketry fire; desires Franklin's assistance in making it known.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing his brother who is about to proceed to Boulogne to transact some business with Mrs. Ogle, a sister of Franklin's old friend, Colonel [Benjamin] Tasker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Condition of M. Dubourg very critical; fears the worst result.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has received Franklin's orders of the 6th inst., respecting the prisoners on board the "Alliance"; hopes that his enclosed letter to the Duke de la Vauguyon will meet with Franklin's approbation; persuaded that Franklin would never wish him to be made the tool of any great King; rejected their dirty piece of parchment; they would have him do that which would render him contemptible even in the eyes of his own servants. Will sail as soon as the wind permits.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intelligence received from. Georgia, disappointing; thinks the English are too much weakened to attempt anything material against the Southern States; letters from Boston of October 28th give an account of the attack on Savannah, the departure of the French fleet, the evacuation of Rhode Island by the English, and the occupation of Newport by Gen. Gates. Eight American prisoners in Bordeaux, captured on board English ships; encloses a letter (2 p.) from one of these (James Jimis) whose case calls for redress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing two memoirs, which he begs Franklin to deliver to M. de Sartine and M. de Vergennes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contrary winds preventing the Commodore's departure. Illness of Mr. Sayre.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: By desire of Commodore Jones, sends him cypher [2 p.] to be used in their correspondence. Hears Mr. William Lee is in town.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to the funcral of M. Barbeu Dubourg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of Philip Mazzei from Ireland, after being captured on his passage from Virginia and imprisoned by the enemy; claims that he is charged with public business of an important nature on which he is ordered to consult with Franklin; will show him every attention if it is Franklin's wish; favorable impression made on him by Mr. Mazzei.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Speaks of Franklin's work on the "Aurora Borealis"; has written upon this subject himself; sends a list of his various scientific works, with notes of their contents; hopes they may prove of some service and interest to Franklin.
(In Italian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosures by Paul Jones [3p.] relative to pensioning an English pilot. John Jackson, who was forced by accident into the service of the United States, in which service he lost his arm. Copies of letters from Admiral Reynst,. the Chevalier de Lironcourt and Commondore Jones [4p.] relative to Jones leaving the Dutch port at once.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing Père Beccaria's answer [XVI, 165] to Franklin's letter, and offering to act as a medium for any further correspondence.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the two bonds respecting the privateers, "Black Prince," Capt. Patrick Dowlin, and the "Black Princess," Capt. Edw. Macatter also copies of the oath of allegiance to the United States, administered to the commanders, officers, and crews of said privateers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing account of General Sullivan's successes against the Indians and Tories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Admiral Reynst's demand that Jones should either fly the French flag or leave the port; reasons in favor of Jones's determination to fly the American colors. Business with M. de. Neufville. Capt. Conyngham on board the "Alliance," as a passenger. Capt. [Richard] Pearson [of H. M. S. "Serapis"] on parole; his sword returned to him.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Dean, Canons and Chapter of The Church of Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to a service in memory of the Archbishop of Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter (2p.) from their friends, Mr. Daniel Crommelin and Son, relative to the payment of certain bills of exchange, with a plan for facilitating such intercourse with Holland in future.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Born in Boston; was in the English service, but escaped, only to be taken prisoner by the French; begs for his freedom and a pass to enable him to go on board a cutter now at Calais; willing and anxious to fight for his country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of the many convivial hours they spent together in Cornhill and Queen Square. Begs that the enclosed, unsealed letter may be forwarded to Capt. Hawker, a worthy officer of His Majesty's 62d regiment of foot, who has been a prisoner in America ever since the convention of Saratoga; desires Franklin's influence to obtain his exchange, as well as that of Major Harnage, as these two are such friends that one will never accept of a release, unless it extends to the other; their miserable and destitute situation. All their old friends at the George and Vulture are alive and well.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is engaged in fitting out two armed frigates with supplies for America; desires to know what objects the Colonists particularly need, and what are the best ports for the sale of his cargo and the purchase of a fresh one.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes a position in the American army; his father a well-known Prussian general.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the birth of his son, who is to be named George; after his dear friend, General Washington; begs Franklin to inform Mr. William Franklin and Dr. Bancroft of the event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes to embark for France in the course of two or three weeks. Alarm felt by the accounts from New York of an invasion of Virginia and the other Southern States, which are not well prepared to oppose them; relies much on the severity of the weather to prevent this expedition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of the frigate, "Sensible," in Spain; report that Mr. Adams is on board with credentials as Minister Plenipotentiary at the Court of London; desires to know if this extraordinary piece of intelligence is true. Would never solicit public employment, but would be highly gratified to be taken notice of by Congress. Order from M. de Chaumont for clothing for 15,000 men.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of the United German Lutheran Ministers to beg Franklin to forward the enclosed letter to His Prussian Majesty's Ambassador or Secretary, to be conveyed in their turn to Hall in Saxony.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A Minister to the Court of Madrid will probably arrive soon; offers to give orders to his banker to furnish him with whatever money be may need during his residence at Court, if Franklin desires it. Hopes it is not true that Comte d'Estaing has been repulsed with loss in an attack Savannah. The blockade of Gibraltar still continues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes at the request of a commerical house at Rouen to find out if Franklin intends appointing a Consul at that place.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just received Surgeon Boutey's petition to Franklin; cannot furnish him with his full share of the prize money for some weeks. Sailing of the "Black Prince" and "Princess" on the 21st inst.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a bill of exchange for acceptance. Offers their services to supply the American troops with uniforms.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prices at which he can procure uniforms, etc., for the soldiers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin of the approaching marriage of her daughter to Vicomte de Tonnerre. Hopes Franklin will pray for their happiness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sure that Franklin will applaud the design of honoring virtue in the person of Jean Jacques Rousseau, of Geneva; encloses the prospectus and begs Franklin to add his name to the list of those who wish to erect a monument to glory.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to write to the Spanish Consul on his behalf; came to Spain as second Captain of a brig from Philadelphia; got into trouble through a dishonest custom's house official; thrown into prison, where he has languished for nine weeks; implores assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Never received a copy of Capt. Jone's letter to Franklin dated October 3d, until December 15th; answers one by one the four general charges laid against him: (1) Disobedience of orders; (2) firing upon the "Bonhomme Richard"; (3) not having assisted the "Bonhomme Richard" as soon as possible; (4) not going in pursuit of the fleet the next day.
(Copy.)

did.unittitle: to Henrey Coder (with Coder Note to Franklin)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing M. Girault, who desires to recommend a firm at Rouen, in case Franklin intends appointing a Consul at that place.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a further declaration by Amsterdam on the subject of the Resolution of November 17th relative to Paul Jones [3p.]. Account of a stormy quarrel between the Grand Facteur and himself. Copy of letter from Paul Jones [1p.] about some small matters on the "Alliance."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heard only a few days before of the death of her revered god-mamma. Is most grateful for Franklin's generosity in regard to the profits from the sale of Gov. Pownall's new edition of her father's map; hopes therewith to educate her four children. Asks for Franklin's literary works with his inscription, "Gift to My Dear Child," on the title page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their admiration and respect for Franklin and their prayers for his preservation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Appointed agent in January, 1779, for the Governor and Council of Virginia. On account of delay in remittances, used his own funds and borrowed more; now, Messrs. D'Acosta, of Nantes, refuse to make him adequate advances on his letter of credit; begs Franklin's advice in the matter.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Messrs. Famin, Devoize and Cie. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Propose to establish an improved distillery for brandy, liquors, etc., in Catalonia, Spain, and describe their plan. Jean Baptiste Famin applies for the appointment of Consul for the United States at Barcelona.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends this letter by M. Gérard; his popularity in Philadelphia; affection they all have for him. Sends furs and newspapers.
(First part missing.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter just received from Mr. Ridley in Maryland; news of Mr. John Adams being appointed to return to Europe and assist in any future treaty of peace; Mr. [John] Laurens appointed Secretary of Embassy at the French Court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The misfortunes of the American troops due principally to want of discipline, and perhaps of vigilance and experience in their commanders; where Gen. Washington has commanded in person things have never gone very ill, but he cannot be everywhere. Offers his services to assist in training the troops.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: [Dr. Franklin's answer, dated May 17, 1779, is printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 348, Bigelow, VI, 387, Smyth, VII, 315).]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laying claim to certain lands in Pennsylvania purchased by his mother's brother, Izaac Maritt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Presenting his respects to Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will call again on Dr. Franklin and Mr. Adams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin and his grandson to dine with him on March 28th.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin and his grandson that they are invited to dine at Mme. Watelets'.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Our Lady of Auteuil [Mme. Helvetius], Abbé de la Roche and himself accept Franklin's invitation. The former does not promise positively, as Franklin seems to prefer the Countess de Forbach to her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regrets not dining with Franklin on Friday. Hopes he will appoint another day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin several packets confided to him by Mr. Vaughan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If Franklin wishes the "Alliance" to remain at L'Orient, he should send his orders to-day, as the mail leaves for Brittany.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the legality of the seizure of the ship "Three Friends," of Dublin, by the American frigate "Alliance."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminds Franklin of the departure of the mail for Brittany in case he has any letters to send to Capt. Landais, of the frigate "Alliance," and gives the address of Chevalier de la Luzerne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommeding a hotel at Versailles where Franklin put up when going to Court.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommends that M. Delatgenetiere, an infantry officer, be reappointed in some regiment.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conway, Françoise-Antoinette-Jeanne Langlois du Bouchet, comtesse de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her husband arrived home three days ago. He will go to Paris to see Franklin soon.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Special instructions given by M. de Sartine that all the vessels of the King and all the corsairs should take precautions not to injure Capt. [James] Cook; thinks it would be well to warn the American corsairs also.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a Captain in the Chamboron Regiment of Hussars. Has offered his services to the Marquis de la Fayette. Wishes Franklin to speak in his favor. Is a friend of the Baron de Breteuil's.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Informing Franklin and his grandson that M. Amelot will dine at home on Monday, November 29th.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a merchant at St. Jean de Luz; presents a claim for a cargo of supplies and munitions of war sent by him in 1778 to Salem, Mass., and for which he never received payment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to help him in carrying out his project of going to America and acquiring a small tract of land for cultivation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Project for a descent on the coast of England and Ireland; probable success of such an expedition, if commanded by Capt. Jones, or some other brave American.
(Part missing.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking indemnity for their vessel first taken by an English corsair, and afterwards recaptured by an American privateer and carried to New York.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her Abbé leaving for London for a visit of several weeks; delighted to undertake any commissions for Franklin; asks for him some letters of recommendation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposal for arming a vessel now at l'Orient.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Items of cost for arming two vessels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Officer in a regiment of dragoons. Is going to the United States. Offers to carry dispatches to Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A ship captain who has just arrived from San Domingo; will call again on Franklin to deliver a letter from Mr. [Jonathan] Williams [Jr.], and confer with him on American interests.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Submitted to Franklin his work entitled "Sovereign Union," on perpetual peace between all rulers and nations of Europe. It was approved by Franklin and by Count de Vergennes. Asks Franklin to allow him to dedicate it to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a school teacher; asks for letters of recommendation to enable him to secure suitable employment.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has finally received the long-sought copy of Eliot's Indian Grammar. Desiring Franklin's presence at the Museum the following Thursday at five o'clock; number of Franklin's acquaintances who will be present.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of the "Revenge" Capt. Conyngham and the prizes she has taken.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a certain bill of exchange drawn by Gourlade and Moylan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Messrs. Franklin and Adams to take tea at her house.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a French merchant going to the American Colonies; wishes to have two letters of introduction from Franklin, one for Boston, the other for Philadelphia.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin "To Jonathan Williams, Esq., Boston, Robert Morris, Esq., Philadelphia."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring on what day Franklin is to dine at M. Hébert's and requesting him to call for her on his way.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of bills drawn on the American Commissioners at Paris.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just returned Versailles, where he went hunting with the King. Hopes Franklin is free by this time of the troublesome gout. The Senegal taken by the Americans. Desires an interview for the discussion of important matters.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented from waiting on Franklin by an attack of fever.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring exact information about the packet which has just brought him a letter from the President of Congress.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented from seeing Franklin by a summons to be present at the King's levée; a foolish law in kingly countries called etiquette; promises to wait on him the next day with news from Versailles.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Ministry awaiting news from Comte d'Estaing before doing anything.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a paper which he intends presenting to the several Ministers, in order to impress them with a favorable opinion of American trade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if Mr. Edward Newenham is in Paris and his address. This information desired by M. de la Fayette, who is still in Lorraine.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A Brigadier-general in the service of the United States; has returned to France; sends Franklin certificates and testimonials given to him by Congress and the general officers of the army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to emigrate to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fell into the hands of English privateers, while on their way to America to enter the service of the State of Georgia. Were imprisoned in England for nearly a year and lost all their money and effects. Appeal for assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is still invalided and cannot go out. Mme. Helvétius sends small seed of Altamaha plant for Franklin's grandson. Asks Franklin to send him a few bottles of Madeira or Sherry wine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. and Mme. d'Andlan are about to leave for England and would willingly take charge of any packages or messages that he might wish to send to friends or acquaintances there.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Send their compliments to Franklin on learning the honorable functions with which he is invested.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends Dr. Franklin the Boston and London papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Franklin ot endorse an enclosed memoir. Wishes to return at once to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has heard that Mr. Adams arrived a few days ago. Asks Franklin to let him know the good news he brought. Thinks he must have brought Franklin's credentials.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Dr. Franklin to dine at the house of Count de Maillebois where he will meet Mr. O'Connell.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests him to postpone his visit to M. de Montalembert, as the latter is unwell. Concerning experiments relative to the aurora borealis. Hopes Franklin will accept M[arquis] de Paulmy's proposition.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Longwell, James. Calais prison, on board the Amphitrite

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His various misfortunes since his capture on board the "Oliver Cromwell," American privateer; begs Franklin to take his case into consideration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes to bring her sister and some mutual friends to dine with him on Sunday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just received the packet for America. Will call to renew his thanks.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Marat, Jean Paul (The Representative of author)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests his presence at the hotel of the Marquis de l'Aubespine, at the repeating of the discoveries made on the igneous fluid. New experiments with the electrical fluid will be performed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His service on the "Bon Homme Richard"; his wounds and subsequent illness; applies for means to go to l'Orient and slip on board an American vessel.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His discovery of a new malleable metal resembling silver. Has established a factory for making all kinds of forks, spoons, and other articles. Gives price-list.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Quoting the "Providence Gazette" [April 26?], announcing the safe arrival of several Continental frigates with eight prizes. Congratulating him on Spain's declaration in favor of the American cause; hopes for a union between Holland and America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Application for indemnity by the owners of the French vessels. "Le Dillon" and "La Fortune," captured at sea by American vessels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offer their services in any capacity in which the Government could use them, while waiting for the end of the war to establish a manufactory for cloth.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to borrow the last American papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter received under cover from London; forwarded the letter to Mr. Oliver by a private hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a package which he received in the mail from London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to hand the memoir on electricity to its author, M. Mauduit.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relative to his previous relations with Mr. Stockton and Mr. Dumas, and his efforts to serve America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explanation of his affairs. Wishes assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His business connections with a certain person [Lord Shelburne?].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging that the packet sent Franklin may be returned at once; obliged to lay one of the papers before the Minister that very morning.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Questions on North America relative to the number of white and black people; the quantity of productions yearly exported from the Colonies; the amount each Colony imports from the metropolis; quantity of productions each Colony receives from other American ports, whether they consume all their imports; the amount of gold and silver on the continent; the amount of paper currency; the sum that the continent is indebted to England, and by what means the people of the metropolis are paid.
(In French and translated.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting an interview about a matter concerning Franklin personally.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: La Rochefoucauld, Louis Alexandre, duc de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks Franklin for the good news from America. Returns his translation in which he has made some corrections. If approved by Franklin, he would undertake to send the manuscript to the Journal.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin's interest on behalf of M. Prosper Mouret of Aix-en-Provence, who desires to go to America and continue his occupation as printer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for money to take him as far as Paris; desires to go on board on American corsair.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the whereabouts of Gabriel Vigeral, who was taken prisoner by the English on board an American privateer in 1778.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiring about Franklin's health.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Franklin to give to bearer the letter he promised.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a letter to Franklin and requesting the latter to send him the latest American gazettes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a few cheeses just received from the Abbaye of Maroilles.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a package which arrived with the despatches from Martinique.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the arrival of the ships from America with rich cargoes— "The Fanny," Captain Tokely, the bark "Tabac," and the ship "La Marie Elizabeth," Captain Young.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notices that the King [Louis XVI] will not hold Court .
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice of change of date for holding Court.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice that Comte de Vergennes will receive Benjamin Franklin on business.
(In French.)

did.physdesc: L.S. de Séqueville. 1p.; L.S. de Sèqueville. 1p.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King will receive the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers on Sunday and Thursday of each week at Fontainebleau.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A ball will be given in the Chateau of Versailles. The King and Queen expect to be present. Orders have been given to have Franklin placed wherever he may wish.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice that the Court will go into mourning.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice that the King will not receive the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers on the 19th of the month.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice that the King will not receive the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers on the 30th, but he will receive them on New Year's Day.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King will hold a Drawing Room next Sunday and receive the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers if they go to Versailles in the morning.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King will not receive the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers next Tuesday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Court will go into mourning on Sunday, the 14th. His Majesty will wear it five days.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King will not receive the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Their Majesties and the Royal Family will go to Marly Sunday, the 22d, and remain until the 1st of June.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Court will go into mourning on the 20th for the death of the Dowager Margravine of Anspach. His Majesty will wear it eleven days.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King will not receive on Tuesday next the Foreign Ambassadors and Ministers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs him to forward to M. Fouquet, in America, an important letter announcing the death of his wife.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the subject of a history he is going to write.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Claim presented for three Spanish trading vessels unlawfuly seized by American privateers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prophesying for America a rigorous and ignominious condition of slavery; is capable by his counsels of maintaining America's tottering independence; begs Franklin to publish this letter in the Mercure de France; will then confide his secret to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relative to the publication of Dr. Franklin's works. Political news. A. L. (Incomplete.) 4 p. List of Dr. Franklin's articles, with their intended order of publication. 2 p. Comments on vis interia. 2 p. Political news. A cure for gout.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accusing Mr. Schweighauser, the agent for America at Nantes, of being in league with the Guernsey privateers.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to send a packet to London by some of Franklin's friends.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting the loan of the Parliamentary Registers which contain the Howe controversy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Leaves Franklin certain English papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Several letters but no news from London. Sir Charles Hardy's fleet at anchor in Plymouth Road on the 17th inst.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assures him that the American papers were returned to Mr. Williams the same day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a newspaper and a correct list of all the regular troops in Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is informed from London that two transports which arrived from New York bring such accounts as incline the people to believe that Gen. Prevost has been beaten near Charleston, with the loss of his artillery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returning the paper Franklin lent him. Promises to write to Mr. Whately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suggestions for improving the value of paper money in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: P. S. [Letter lost.] If honored by Dr. Franklin's notice he will pay his personal respects to him. He has a son, aged 20, in the mercantile line in England who will assist him. Letters addressed to Mr. Freeman, under cover of G. M. Coote, Esa., M.P., Dublin, will be sent to him by that gentleman into the country, and be franked to him from England, notwithstanding that Irish members cannot at present frank them there or out of their own kingdom—a privilege which is yet to be received by this once oppressed but now rising country, for which she may thank America and her volunteer corps.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to send anything which he wishes to have published about the American Colonies in the enclosed paper to M. Derival, at Brussels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Observations on the necessity and advantages of having another commercial centre and port on the Mediterranean besides Marseilles. Limitations of the latter port. Proposes La Seyne, near Toulon, as a new port.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives rates for freighting vessels and advises Franklin not to pay more that 200 livres per ton.
(In French. Incomplete.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposes to supply three or four hundred barrels of wine and a quantity of brandy for consumption in the United States, in exchange for leaf tobacco from Virginia. Offers to act as Consular agent for the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Memorial on commercial relations between France and the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commerce between Switzerland and the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A project for raising a regiment to invade England, Ireland and Scotland.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin letters which he has just received for him from Miss Shipley.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Departure of the courier of the Ambassador the following day; desires his translation of Franklin's letter together with the letter of M. de Vergennes and the Commission of Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to go to America; remorse from a dishonorable action; will guard the secret of his real name until he receives Franklin's answer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to fifty-six bills of exchange.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Trouble brought upon him and the Commandant-General by the behavior of Capt. Conyngham, who obtained the release of four sailors and an officer, prisoners of war, on the understanding that he would make good any charges, should the Court at Madrid disapprove of their release; this promise he failed to keep.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a poem, "The Complaint of the King of England," in which he eulogizes France and Franklin and vilifies England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a large order received from le Comte de Montfort to supply the hussrs at Philadelphia with various articles of clothing; in case the Count should be killed or the vessel taken, desires Franklin to keep the account of the articles, after he has seen them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of the "Serapis," "Pallas," and "Countess of Scarborough," with the brigantine, "Vengeance"; no mention made of Capt. Jones; imagines he proceeded through the Channel with the "Alliance."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: None of his former requests for assistance have been answered.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thinks the proposition for peace in May and June did some good, although opposed by the Ministry. Is strongly in favor of proposing a ten years' truce to America; part France would play in such an offer; objects to demanding the removal of troops as a preliminary measure; difficulties which confront the peace-maker; would take a bare-foot pilgrimage to Mecca to be assured of safe grounds to act upon; peace negotiations reported to be the object of Mr. Adams's mission; urges Franklin to be ever watchful for this great result.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has promised that Franklin would write to M. le Comte de Broglie, recommending M. Lair De Lamotte, M. Dubourg's nephew, for the position of Secretary.
[Enclosed is a letter of introduction (1 p.), unsigned.]
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Col. [Patrick] Ferguson's defeat has frustrated, in a great measure, the enemy's designs against Virginia, but it is feared they will winter in Portsmouth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Born in Baltimore; shipped as officer in the first cruise of the "Bon Homme Richard"; was wounded and left, at his own expense, at l'Orient; desires a sufficient sum to enable him to redeem his trunk and clothes.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Veuve Dque Morel and fils. Dunkirk

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of a portion of Commodore Jone's fleet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has shipped the paper; M. Beaumarchais's agent, M. Le Tailleir, returns to England in three weeks and will take charge to any letters; he has purchased Baskerville type for Voltaire's works. Superiority of English over foreign papers. Talk concerning peace very confident.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a bill of exchange payable at sight; good wishes for the success of the American cause.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: de Peliepore, Abbé de la Fitte. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a packet of letters for M. Plombard, the French Consul at Charleston; is very uneasy concerning his brother, the Chevalier de la Fitte.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discusses the question of a ten years' truce in all its aspects; his reasons for treating with the present Ministry; rumor of Sir H. Clinton having been instructed to treat with America; if this is true, desires to know what terms he offered; Spanish papers report that the British Ministry, while openly avowing hopes of reconciliation, were bribing France to abandon America. Conjectures as to the object of Mr. [John] Adams's mission to Europe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing copies of the new protestations by certain Dutch towns against the Resolution in the States-General of Nov. 19th. [In French 5 p.] Departure of Capt. Jones and the squadron. His quarrel with the Grand Facteur; accused by him of having blackened the character of M. G[ran]d in Franklin's eyes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written several letters to Franklin, offering to go to Philadelphia and establish a Military School there; expects his expenses to be defrayed; offers made by the British.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter from Mr. [William] Smith (XVII, 10, see p. 203) to whom he rendered some service; hopes Franklin will interest himself in Smith's case.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote two months before respecting his method for coloring cotton, wool and yarn, an art for which England, France and Spain offered £1,000 each; prefers to sail for America carrying his secret with him rather than obtain the premium from any one of these Kingdoms; on account of his losses in England and his long stay in Holland, is unable to carry out this plan without Franklin's assistance; should this fail, will be obliged, sorely against his will, to apply to Sir Joseph Yorke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Since the exchange of the English prisoners, as he refused to be classed in that category, his allowance has been stopped and he has subsisted solely on Franklin's small donation; cannot sail for Martinique until the end of the month, and not then, unless Franklin advances him a small sum for the discharge of his debts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has decided to sail for America in the spring; the best and safest way of conveying his family across the Atlantic. Before leaving Europe, would like to tell Franklin something of interest which he cannot trust to paper.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Corail de Sainte-Foy, François de. Toulouse

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of two brave officers in the service of the Emperor, sends Franklin the two enclosed packets.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was in the Prussian service. Offers his services to the United States.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: von Weckherlein, Major Gottlieb Christian. Anspach

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to Lieut-General von Saldern, under whom he served. Offers his services to the American cause.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Surprised at not hearing from Franklin for two months, relative to the Cartel; sends copy of letter from the Board of Sick and Hurt, dated November 15th, 1779. [See XVI, 109.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival in port of the "Black Prince", after being hotly pursued by two English frigates; since the 21st of December, she made five prizes and four ransoms; the prisoners, numbering forty-eight, will be landed and cared for.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interview with M. de Montbarrey, on the subject of forwarding military supplies for the American Army.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 410).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving fictitious names under cover of which their correspondence can be safely forwarded. Gives memoranda concerning maps of Great Britain and Ireland, bought by order of William Temple Franklin and lately shipped via Amsterdam. Also enclose bill for books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extracts from the letter of John P. Jones to Dr. Franklin, dated at the Texel, October 3d, 1779; begs Franklin to certify that they are a true copy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to assist him.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his efforts to obtain military supplies for the American army.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 411).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complaints against England's treatment of Dutch ships. The "Serapis," "Scarborough," "Pallas" and "Vengeance" said to be safe at Dunkirk; whereabouts of the "Alliance." M. de Neufville's accounts.
(In French.)

did.unitdate: [1779 Before June 10] [1780 On or After Aug 31]

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Safe arrival of the squadron under Commodore Jones; the settlement of their expenses. Terms of a certain loan. Question of passports for some of their friends who intend to enrage in the American business. Had the pleasure of seeing Baron [de] Wülffen, Aide-de-camp to the great Gen. Washington. Rumor of the French and Spanish fleets having joined forces. Promising to forward Franklin a portrait of Gen. Washington, designed for him, by some one whose name, at present, is a secret. Report from America of the taking of St. Lucia, Barbadoes and Antigua.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding a copy of the journal of the "Black Princess"; arrival of two of her prizes, and one belonging to the "Black Prince"; begs for their speedy condemnation. Uneasy at hearing no tidings of the "Black Prince."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses list of prisoners taken by the "Black Prince," which sailed on the 11th for Brest, where she expected to find her prizes awaiting her; report received of the arrival of only one.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to pay his respects to Franklin.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Le Veillard, Geneviève-Elisabeth Belamy (Louis-Guillaume's wife). Dreux

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him for the prettiest little desk in the world; its only fault is that it failed to contain a letter saying that he still loved her a little; hopes in a month to be again at Passy where she may once more embrace him; messages from her father and mother; if the desk is his grandson's choice, considers him a young man of extraordinary good taste.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his capture of the two Swedish ships; without the ship's papers, can say no more. Question of the accusations brought against him and their utter falsity; expected to have his conduct justified ere this.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notification of bills of exchange furnished to the States of RhodeIsland and New York.
(In triplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been granted a passage, by the Minister of Marine, upon the first vessel sailing for North America; hears that the Continental frigate, the "Committee," sails from Nantes in a few days; desires a letter of recommendation to Franklin's Agent in Nantes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has forwarded particulars of the first fine success of the "Black Prince" and "Princess." Has purchased that day, for the brave Capt. Luke Ryan, the fine large cutter lately commanded by Capt. Royer, which is to be called the "Fearnot"; asks for an American Commission for the Captain. Sixty-six prisoners taken by the above-mentioned ships, are landed and at Franklin's disposal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs that the enclosed letter may be forwarded.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His safe passage through the Channel, in spite of the enemy's attempts to cut off his retreat; would have given them cause for fresh alarm, had not his sails and rigging been in such a bad condition; description of a brigantine from Liverpool, sailing under Dutch colors, which he took and sent to America; extremely vexatious to see the enemy carrying on half their trade under neutral colors; expects to proceed towards his destined port in France; reasons why he thinks the Court cannot refuse to fit out his ship upon her arrival.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His position of Governor of the Royal Military School at Colmar; his long-cherished desire to serve in the American army; is twenty-five years old. Wishes to know what steps he must take to carry out his plan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for a letter of introduction for his wife's grandfather, John Aitcheson, from M. d'Estaing to the Governor or to some principal person in the Island of Grenada.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging for the release of eight Irish prisoners, who have sworn allegiance to the United States, and who have been promised berths in the crew of the "Fearnot"; much in want of such good sailors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses letter for his father in Yorkshire; in case his son-in-law [step-son] William Royal is sent to America via France, asks Franklin to recommend him to the care of some good Captain coming to Virginia.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending his friend, Dominique François Belletti.
(In Italian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The arrival of the "Black Prince" at l'Orient some days before; during eighteen days' cruise in the English Channel, she made several captures and deposited forty-eight prisoners; desires to know if they are to be regarded as the property of the United States, in which case, they must be distinguished from the prisoners of France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing letters for the Hon. John Adams, whose agreeable company they have been enjoying and who sets out for Paris on the 20th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One of his relatives, a young officer, desires to serve in the American army; requests information as to the expense of the voyage and the articles needed.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to the taking of St. Eustace and the consternation caused by the news in the English Colony at Nice. Her house is next to that of Lady Rivers (formerly Mrs. Pitt). Tells of a concert given at the latter's house at which Mme. Brillon played the "Insurgent's March" composed by herself. Account of a conversation with Lord Cholmondeley on the same occasion. He is desirous to meet Franklin and promises to take tea at Mme. Brillon's house at Passy.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They desire Franklin's advice in regard to the payment of a draft.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for news of Mrs. Carroll, a relative of his wife, and wishes to know if Mr. Carroll will be Franklin's successor, in the event of his quitting France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In receipt of news from America; his interest in his own country and in Franklin's should be a close bond of union between them.
(In French.)
Agreement attached relative to the vessel, the "Marquis de la Fayette."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Claims that he was promised the position of Captain of Marines, by Commodore Guillin [Gillon], who told him to await at Nantes the orders he would send by Capt. [William] Robeson; has heard nothing since; his letters unanswered and he himself reduced to the last degree of poverty and misery; begs for assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promised, by Mr. Williams, a passage to America on board the "Marquis de la Fayette"; unable to wait longer for the departure of this vessel; asks for a passage on one of the French frigates shortly to sail from Brest to Rhode Island; will be glad to carry any despatches and would be obliged for an introduction to Congress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter [1 p.] from the Baron de la Houze relative to the two prizes seized at Bergen and restored to the English. Anxious for tidings of Paul Jones, also for news of the ship "Confederacy," carrying Messrs. [John] Jay and [William] Carmichael.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Sayn et Wittgenstein, Jean-Louis, comte de. Wittgenstein

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Since 1776, le Sieur Lutterloh has owed him and his subjects a large sum of money; believes him, at present, to be serving with distinction in Washington's army; thinks he will be willing to pay his debts if he has the means; begs for Franklin's mediation.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has taken three valuable prizes, four ransoms, and put forty-three captives into the prison at l'Orient; his consort; the "Black Princess," boasts four prizes, will send copy of journal and the names of the prisoners; hopes shortly to be ready to join the "Black Princess" at the Ile of Ross.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Having received no answer to his letter of Nov. 23rd, presumes it miscarried; miserable condition of the American prisoners, who number 1,100; does not understand why nothing has been done to forward the exchange as the English Board of Sick and Hurt are most anxious to do their part; another passport needed, as two vessels will not be sufficient.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His health perfectly restored; waits with impatience the commission for his ship the "Fearnot"; his refusal of offers made by the French will only serve under the American flag; refuses to expose himself to the insults of French officers. His scheme for the Bristol fair of March, will, he hopes, deprive the fair of some linen and other cargoes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Departure of Mr. Adams from Bayonne. His reasons for thinking the "Confederacy" has foundered; bewails the difficulty and uncertainty of correspondence with the United States; suggests the benefits of having monthly packet boats; in daily expectation of valuable arrivals from America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Referring Franklin to their letter of the 12th inst.; enclosing a copy of the journal of the "Black Prince"; their anxiety lest two of the prizes taken by the "Princess" have been retaken or lost; think both privateers will be ready for sea again in a few days; need of the prizes being speedily judged and condemned, on account of the great demand for provisions in the French navy.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Fleury, Lieut.-Col. François Louis Teisseidre de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking to have his medal [ordered by the Congress] struck by the following week, as the King desires to see it; suggestions for the design.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promising to send the twelve reams of paper as soon as it has been marbled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Irritation of a certain great person against the English owing to their treatment of the Dutch ships; his expressed intention to propose a new resolution in favor of unlimited convoys, annulling all subsequent bills opposed to this measure. Information concerning the Baron de la H[ouze].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His claim, through Ralph Fretwell, to a considerable tract of land in Chester County, Pa.; has the original warrant; desires advice as to how to proceed in the matter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Dr. Franklin and Mr. John Adams to tea.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been authorized by M. Necker to write a treatise on the comparative cultivation of tobacco; among other works, has need of one on the cultivation of tobacco in Virginia published in England a few years before; if it is in Franklin's possession, begs him to forward it with any other treatises on the subject he may be able to procure; relies on M. Necker and the Chevalier de Keralio to speak for him in this matter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The unanimous resolution of the Holland Assembly for unlimited convoys. Not yet the right moment to propose a treaty to Holland. Account of a M. G(u)illon at Amsterdam, who passes as a United States Admiral and has the confidence of M. Van Berkel and other distinguished persons; suspects some intrigue like that of Mr. W[illam] L[ee] or Mr. Izard.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will send his servant for an answer to the question enclosed on a separate paper herein.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of Pierre Colomb, who desires to enter the service of the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs for a sufficient sum to enable him to return to his own country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rumor that Capt. Jones is cruizing off the coast of Ireland. Baron de la H[ouze] not to be trusted. Anxious concerning the fate of the "Confederacy."
(In English; partly in cipher.).

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Boyd, William R. et al. Nantes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Petition for relief, from seamen belonging to Capt. Green's vessel which was sunk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires Franklin to forward him the judgment of the prize ship "La Providence," taken by the "Black Prince"; the sale to take place on the 6th of March.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Admiralty having omitted to send an account of their procedure in regard to the prize captured by the "Black Prince," takes it upon himself to perform this duty; M. Diot only awaits Franklin's decision before allowing the sale to take place.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been in Paris since January 15th, awaiting at least his reinstatement to the command of the "Alliance"; all his possessions left on board that frigate; demands money to replace these things, and also for his daily expenses.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's Franklin in France, I, 323.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges receipt of letter of November 21, 1779. Announces the death of his wife. Begs that the enclosed letter be forwarded to his son.
(In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrived from Virginia the day before; expected to find Mr. Jay in Paris, but has just heard that he is in Cadiz; hopes Franklin will advise Mr. Jay how to proceed; has letters of recommendation to M. Beaumarchais and other gentlemen.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Description of the clothing to be prepared for the American soldiers; promises to send the model of a hat; if the money of Congress is not sufficient, will answer for the rest; great importance of getting these articles to America before the compaign opens; necessity of the officers also having suitable clothing.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His reasons for returning to port so soon; wretched condition of the "Alliance"; does not boast one good rope or sail; blames this state of things on Capt. Landais's slothfulness and ignorance. His health rather impaired from his late fatigues; has been almost blind with sore eyes. Steps he intends taking to repair the "Alliance," Wishes the "Serapis" could be made the property of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival at Cadiz of Mr. [John] Jay and M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval] from Martinique. Account of the doings of the active Bareclo and the steps taken by him to protect his ships. Various reports of operations in the West Indies where it is apprehended that the English will be active.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrival of Capt. Jones on the 10th inst., as well as Mr. Haywood in the ship "Governor Livingston" from Virginia; when she left port, four thousand British troops were expected on one of their characteristic visits to Chesapeake Bay, and four thousand more were designed for Georgia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expressing their thanks for their appointments to serve under Captain Ryan, of the "Fearnot."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the acceptance of certain bills. Desires to know if he is to observe the directions of Congress only as regards the uniforms, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Heard from Jones himself of his arrival at Corunna, January 16th.
(In French; partly in cipher.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Ingham Foster in perfect health; Mr. Aubert in danger of his life, and his great friend, Sir James Burrow, seriously ill; the illness of his friends together with his own misfortunes he finds sorely depressing.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Conti, Louis-François-Joseph de Bourbon, comte de la Marche and prince de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting passports for two of his huntsmen who go to England to procure him horses.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unable to get his remittances from home; obliged, therefore, to return to America with his family; has not sufficient money to make a long journey before sailing, so is obliged to go directly to New York; begs for a letter to the Governor of the Jerseys, and a few lines to a friend of Franklin in Philadelphia, mentioning the cause of his coming to America by way of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning an American bill in his possession which he wishes to have negotiated.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the strength of his former services in America, begs Franklin to forward the enclosed letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No reply to his various appeals for help; fears he has unwittingly offended Franklin; his end is near; cannot die tranquilly without the assurance of Franklin's forgiveness.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certain repairs on the "Alliance" absolutely necessary; promises economy. Unless the prize money is paid, his throat will assuredly be cut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Emboldened by the interest Franklin has shown in his "Table Raisonné de l'Economic Politique," begs permission to dedicate his present work to him,—a moral and political catechism.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Not necessary to have the "Alliance" heaved down; repairs needed. Hopes that the wages due the surviving seamen of the late "Bon Homme Richard" may be paid them at once. His eyes still very weak and inflamed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received the enclosed letter from Mr. Bache, of Philadelphia, in June, 1778, but has been unable to deliver it sooner. In Europe concerning a legacy left his father. Before leaving America, he commanded a company in the Continental service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his favors of May 26th and December 30th. The Commercial Committee impressed with Franklin's sentiments respecting draughts. Brighter prospect of suitable remittances since the Resolve of December 14th, Chevalier de la Luzerne strongly in favor of a correspondence by cipher; encloses a very good one (1 p.), though a little tedious.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging the receipt on board his vessel, the "Happy Return," of a long list of English prisoners, taken by the American corsair, the "Black Prince."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires news of his son, a secretary under M. [Conrad Alexandre] Gérard [de Rayneval]; begs for that gentleman's present address.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the safe arrival of Mr. Jay and the other passengers on board the "Aurore." Desires to know if the cannon purchased by Franklin's order could be conveyed to America in the " Alliance."

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the four thousand suits of clothes which must be at La Rochelle by March 2d, if they are to go on the frigate which takes him to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing the receipt of the English Captain, Wm. Webb, for the twenty-eight American prisoners received on board his ship, the "Happy Return."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nothing accomplished by the Holland Assembly; more talk of increasing the navy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certificate as Consul of France given to Captain Boullancourt.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Promises to be as economical as possible. Will gladly carry the supply of arms and clothing to America and will do his best to accommodate the four gentlemen mentioned as passengers. In great want of a first lieutenant; the present incumbent oftener drunk than sober; would consider it a great favor if he could have Lieut. Rhodes, now on board the "Luzerne." His letter to Mr. Baudouin written to remove any prejudice against himself which might prove hurtful to the common cause. Question of prize money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 14th inst. The petition of the poor American is perfectly true; his sufferings from illness and poverty genuine; will make inquiry about the man, and reward those who befriended him; this is only one of many cases met with at all sea-ports; has a heavy charge against the State for these advances.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Fleury, Lieut.-Col. François Louis Teisseidre de. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has written to Congress and to General Washington asking for an extension of his furlough; thinks a word from Franklin might procure him this favor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Introducing Thomas Kearl, of Norfolk, who desires to know the best way of returning to his native country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring to know if the prisoners taken by American ships are permitted to enter the American service; many can be found willing to do this; great need of men on board the American vessels; if such an arrangement is feasible, asks that M. Puchelberg, the agent of Congress, may be informed of the fact.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the dishonest conduct of one Thomas Neweil, who declared he was bound for the Bay of Honduras and made application for goods on freight; instead of this, he proceeded to the Danish island of St. Thomas and there disposed of his partner, Mr. Barry's property and that of the other shippers; desires Franklin's influence to help him obtain some redress.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
