scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the Spanish loan. Unjustifiable treatment of Mr. Laurens.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Hale's "Franklin in France" I, 415.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been six weeks in the country; pines for a sight of Franklin; has met a Genoese noble called M. de Silezia, who was entrusted with a packet for Franklin; their united wish to dine at Passy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers found in Mr. [Henry] Laurens's valise; correspondence between W[illia]m Lee and M. de Neufville concerning a treaty between America and Holland; M. Van Berkel involved in it; his conduct endorsed by Amsterdam; Mr. [Samuel W.] Stockton's letters, found in the valise, written to a Mr. Whitestone have given undying offense to a great person.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Waiting for permission to accept the last-mentioned bills on Mr. [Henry] Laurens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All the expense of the "Ariel" borne by their house; arrival at l'Orient of a cargo of merchandise which has been stored until further orders from Franklin.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Walter Williams and Helenus Scott. Leghorn

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolved to go to America and assist the great cause. Two letters to the same effect.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing that the mail from Philadelphia due the previous evening, was seized in the dead of night at Stratford by the enemy and carried to Long Island; thinks the bills mentioned in the enclosed Resolve were in that mail. His son again on his way to Europe; hopes the same civility may be shown him as on his former trip; the demand on his son from France was honorably acquitted; absolute faith in the young man's perfect integrity. Positive intelligence received of Mr. [Henry] Laurens's imprisonment.

did.physdesc: A.L.S. James Lovell. 2p.; L.S. Jas. Lovell, Wm. Churchill Houston 7p.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: The Continental Congress, Committee on Foreign Affairs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a committee appointed by Congress to draught a letter with certain instructions to their Ministers at the Courts of Versailles and Madrid; desires Franklin to communicate to Mr. Adams what appears so much connected with his commission.
Three enclosures; the first, recommending that some acknowledgement he made of the services of M. Chasseaulx, Consul at Bergen; the second and third relating to bills of exchange.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to the Committee of Congress appointed on the 6th inst. to draft a letter to the Ministers at Madrid and Marseilles, and to the report of the 17th inst. Papers for John Jay will be sent through Dr. Franklin's hands, and begs the latter to forward them to Mr. Jay, first reading those which are left unsealed.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Owing to a financial loss; obliged to take lodgers; applies to Franklin to recommend her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Being disappointed at the non-appearance of Mr. Laurens, addresses himself to Franklin and offers to supply everything in the nature of artillery for the United States; will await Franklin's orders through M. Dumas.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His ship unfit for sea, having been damaged in a gale of wind; wishes to be appointed to another ship; has one hundred officers and men ready to step on board; understands that the "Furepscord," now in the harbor, has no one yet in command.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the bills drawn on Mr. Laurens; newspapers mention that the papers found with Mr. Laurens related in part to the City of Amsterdam and that they will be printed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His unfortunate condition and his inability to fulfill his engagements; would not be in his present difficulties, had he not been too honest in serving the Americans with the best merchandise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning bills forwarded for acceptance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His brother, Christian Wilhelm Ruthardt, went to Philadelphia in 1774. A recent letter says he is dead. Desires information. Offers to supply shoes for American troops.
(In German.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had a brother, Christian Guillaume Ruthardt, who went to America six years ago and settled in Philadelphia. Heard a report recently that he was dead. Asks Franklin to make inquiry about him in Pennsylvania and send proof of his death.
(Translation in French by Comtesse de Golofkin.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is not yet leaving for America. M. de Vauban, a French officer, leaves to-day for Brest where he will embark. The latter would willingly take charge of Franklin's packets and deliver them to M. de La Perouze, Captain of the frigate "Amazone," who is about to set sail for America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for news of M. Bedaulx, of Switzerland, Colonel in the United States army, whose relatives are uneasy in regard to his fate.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has shipped copying machines, with paper and ink powder; gives directions for the use of the powder; account of money expended.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill of exchange on the American Commissioners in favour of George Gartner. Attested copy of D.S. F.Hopkinson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extract of the Resolution in the Holland Assembly relative to the papers about the treaty found in Mr. Lauren's valise, together with the letter from the Burgomasters of Amsterdam on this subject [8 p.]; M. Van Berkel entirely justified.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have accepted the bills drawn on Mr. Laurens; had the honor to wait on Mr. Adams who gave them leave to present the remaining bills.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The order of the Farmers-General for the free export of saltpetre received, but owing to certain news from I'Orient, they discontinued the shipment; all the details are in the enclosed letter to Mr. Williams
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Willcocks, Robert et al. Forton prison

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Certifying that Mr. Joseph Lunier was taken as passenger on board the "Mackerel," prize of the brig "Notre Dame" belonging to South Carolina, he was subsequently captured and has been confined upwards of three years in Forton prison.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transmitting orders respecting bills of exchange; calls attention to a printer's error in the emission in execution of the Resolution of Congress of August 3, 1780.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note of bills of exchange issued.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Declaring his inability to pay the twenty thousand pounds in bills of exchange drawn on Mr. Laurens; if Franklin will become responsible for them at present, will endeavor to borrow a sufficient sum to meet them.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 513).

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: ------------, de Kemtenstrauss et al La Société Raguerante. Munich

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of a number of gentlemen whose plan is to establish a colony in the United States; the conditions are entire liberty of conscience, a certain number of acres, all privileges accorded to other inhabitants, and the administration of their own affairs without interference.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sentiments which every religious subject must hold, especially in times of war; apologizes for his rustic attempt; is but a poor curé with no knowledge of literary methods.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends certified copy of Resolution of Congress of October 14, 1780. in reference to the issue of sets of exchange in place of those lost. Notification of issue of same.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Attentions to American prisoners in Ireland; has procured the release of thirteen since the first of July. Sympathy of the Irish people entirely with the United States. Condition of affairs in Ireland; corruption in Parliament. Hopes to settle three of his five sons in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Applied with Mr. Robert Temple at the Board of Sick and Hurt, who said that no exchange of prisoners from Boston to England would be admitted, nor could they be exchanged by receipt; desire to know if they went to France and surrendered to Franklin, whether their exchange could then be effected and their parole cancelled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The French Ambassador desirous of aiding Franklin in the affair of Saba. News of Mr. Lauren's unhappy situation; his own bitter disappointment about the Secretaryship; Mr. Searle's promise to write to Congress on his behalf; reasons why he sorely needs the money. End of the affair of the papers discovered in Mr. Laurens's valise; good and bad results of the business.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Quoting certain extracts from the memoirs of the "Société de Berne," regarding population, to the effect that in general the mortality in towns is greater than in the country, but in cases of epidemic, the country is the greater sufferer; gives probable reasons for this.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apologizing for delay in sending the papers relative to the shipping of saltpetre from St. Malo to l'Orient.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is much indebted for his kindness on behalf of his friend Mr. James Cheston, who will deliver the present letter. Trusts Franklin has recovered from his indisposition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Particulars of her journey from Marseilles to Nice. Her health beginning to improve. Nice an ideal place for health-seekers. Everyone she met spoke highly of Franklin. The Count d'Estaing is very popular with the sailors and the people in general in the different ports she visited.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for recommending him as a translator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a draft of a letter to Dr. Franklin which he may write to Mr. and Mme. Poivre, of Lyons.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Virulent memoir presented to the States-General by Sir Joseph Yorke.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Difficulties and delays experienced in loading the "Marquis de la Fayette"; dispute between M. de Chaumont and himself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. Chantel has no doubt given Franklin an account of his serious illness. When his work on Natural Electricity is completed, will send Franklin a copy; being no longer able to continue his observations, has determined to collect those of the last twenty years; hopes that if it fails to instruct the public, it will at least divert them.
(In Italian.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Since his unfortunate return, has received two letters from Mr. Gourlade wherein it appears Franklin blames him for certain charges in the accounts against the United States; reasons why he ordered the articles in question; has no other motive than the advancement of the service. The "Ariel" will again be ready for sea in the course of a week.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Her opinion of Franklin's "Dialogue with the Gout"; begs him not to let M. Veillard, Abbé de la Roche, etc., touch up his French; thinks his style is weakened by the influence of grammarians.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Proceedings of American Philosophical Society, XL, 103, and in Putnam's Monthly, October 1906, 35.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The fertility of imagination displayed by the enemy in all that relates to America; advisability of authentic accounts. Enclosing papers giving particulars of Major [Patrick] Ferguson's defeat on King's Mountain, South Carolina. Some troops landed by the enemy at Portsmouth, Va., but are held there by the miltia. Congress has forbidden all short enlistments and voted an army of thirty-five thousand men for the war. As the affair of the late Adjutant-General of the British army [André] may be misrepresented, encloses proceedings; also an account which places Arnold's past character upon its proper footing. Transcribes a Resolve of Congress concerning the virtuous and patriotic conduct of three young men, [John] Paulding, [David] Williams and [Issac] Van Wart, in intercepting and making prisoner, Major John André. Mutual harmony and affection between the French and American troops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has no doubt that the news of Arnold's treason has come to hand; expresses his opinion of such base conduct and the motives for it; he has been sentenced to be publicily reprimanded by General Washington; is perfectly willing to have this letter quoted to support the truth of these charges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been forced to remain longer in Paris than he had expected; wishes to know if this delay will make a difference regarding the letters to Capt. Jones confided to his care.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter just received from M. Moylan.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends a letter to be forwarded to Baron Von Steuben concerning the manufacture of saltpetre in the United States. Desires, on his own account, the position of colonel of artillery, and for a friend the rank of major with certain emoluments.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to establish himself in the United States as a druggist.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From Paris. Details concerning the freighting of his vessel, the "Marquis de la Fayette"; his reasons for wishing her to sail directly from Bordeaux. Desires certain bills settled.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has the honor of presenting to Franklin his first verses dedicated to liberty.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. [Pierre] Colombe, served with distinction in the United States, was taken prisoner; unable to procure his exchange, he desires a position in the French army.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to send to America a young man who posses a thorough knowledge of handwriting and arithmetic.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sees no objection to the proposal made by the Director-General of Finances that a letter of credit be drawn on Congress for the needs of the French troops; has no recollection of refusing a similar proposal made to him by Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Much obliged for M. de Chaumont's offers but his men not willing to go to Bordeaux; should M. de Chaumont give him the command of the vessel, his officers and men would then undertake the journey with pleasure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has just received a letter from M. Gourlade, of which the enclosed [2 p., in French] is an extract; in consequence has written the within letters [3 p.] to the new Minister of Marine and M. de Chaumont, claiming prize-money for the "Bon Homme Richard" and the "Alliance," while under his command; if Franklin thinks these letters suitable, begs his influence to support them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Received Franklin's favor of the 13th inst. and has accepted the bills; if he does not succeed in his efforts to arrange a loan, will draw upon Franklin when they become payable; on his arrival believed that money might be had upon the credit of the United States; such a consummation prevented by the news from South Carolina and New York, and above all by the affair of the Burgomaster and Sir Joseph Yorke's memorial.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is about to begin his course of lectures; begs the honor of Franklin's presence at the first one.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Was much moved to see in the Gazette the death of her brother, General de Kalb(e); as she is his only near, surviving relative, begs to be informed what possessions her brother left in America and in what way she may obtain them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending notes or coments on a dialogue written in French by Franklin. Thinks he expresses himself more forcefully than would a grammarian. Remains Franklin of his promise to give her a printed copy of his works.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Proc. Am. Phill. Soc., XL,108.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Vergennes, Charles Gravier, comte de. Versailles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the Resolutions of Congress ordering drafts upon Franklin; astonished at being asked for the necessary funds to meet them will endeavor to procure for him next year the same aid he has been able to furnish during the present one.
(In French. Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hopes Franklin will help him to go to America.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Jacques François Crespin and Aimable Titoix. Dunkirk

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served with Capt. Conyngham on the "Revenge"; have been deprived of their share of the prize-money and also their pay for nearly three years, during which time they languished in English prisons; beg for assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dispute between M. de Chaumont and himself decided in his favor. Two gentlemen of his own appointing (M. Rozée and M. Montaudouin) have decided the freight to be payable only after the goods are loaded at l'Orient and Messrs. Jauge and Co. (Mr. de Chaumont's correspondents) of Bordeaux, have, of their own accord, reduced the measurement of the ship to a reasonable tonnage. Requests him to send his dispatches for the "Mars" by return of post as she will by that time be ready to sail. The "Hercules," Captain [John] Carey, bound to Baltimore, of sixteen guns and eighty men, will sail with the "Mars."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extract from the instructions to B[enjamin] Franklin.
(Press copy.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Diplom. Corres. of Am. Rev., Wharton, IV, 163.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begs Franklin to send him the corrected proof.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Franklin's financial burdens. Mr. Searle's sanguine picture of American affairs. Affairs in Holland. A gentleman in Amsterdam commissioned by England to hire as many vessels as he possibly can to carry troops to America.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Works (Sparks, VIII, 518).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: M. [de] Mauduit [Duplessis] will be at her house Wednesday evening with an officer who desires to meet Franklin. This officer had captured an English vessel.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Holland's agreement to an armed neutrality; resolution disapproving and disavowing Amsterdam's letter as to an eventual treaty between America and Holland; the Holland Assembly deliberating on the answer to be given to Sir Joseph Yorke's insolent memoir.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Did not think it right to keep his crew until the present date at thier owner's expense; has found places for most of them on American vessels. If the gentleman will give him the command of the cutter mentioned, will set out for Dunkirk at once with his officers, and has no doubt of meeting with success; is well acquainted with the coast of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends report from the Commitee of the House of Commons relative to French and Spanish prisoners. Hopes, with Franklin's assistance, to obtain the agency for the inspection of prisoners in Great Britain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Robert Mease, of Alexander, Va., proposes to visit several places in France and to pass some time in Paris; recommends him to Franklin's civility and protection; the devotion of Mr. Mease and his family to the great cause of liberty is well-known.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's kindness in endeavoring to obtain Capt. Courter and his crew for the privateer of M. Salomes; desires to name this vessel after Franklin; inspiration of such a title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Just from an English prison; was Surgeon on the "Morris" and the "Retaliation"; the salary still due him; begs for assistance and employment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken prisoner in January, 1777; made his escape on the 23d ult. from Forton prison; hoped to find an American Agent at Havre who would advance him a small sum, but was disappointed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing a letter just arrived from England.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes employment for himself and six sons as agents and correspondents in German cities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commodore Jones only waiting for Franklin's despatches to set sail; beg that they may be forwarded at once.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been ready for sea these five days past and only waiting for Franklin's despatches; hopes also for despatches from Court in consequence of advices received from Rhode Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging Franklin's favor of the 24th of October; laid the account of prisoners released before the Board of Sick and Hurt; still forty-one prisoners due, and no more exchanges until that debt is paid; account of the expenditure of one hundred pounds, received from M. Grand for the relief of prisoners; one hundred more lately committed to Forton; nothing further to be expected from public subscriptions; men afraid to show common sentiments of humanity towards Americans. Sorry to announce the death of their mutual friend, Mr. [Thomas] Bentley; much regretted by the old Club.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has been entirely occupied in the contemplation of Nature; principally in regard to the influence of the vegetable kingdom upon the animal, and with the essential ingredients out of which the atmosphere is composed; intends soon to lay before the public the result of these experiments; explains his change of opinion on the effect on air caused by vegetables. Has made use of the several metal wires given him; details his method of employing them; will make no further use of this investigation save what Franklin, who furnished the materials and suggested the method of inquiry, may think proper. Desires to know if his book was well received in France; German and Dutch translations published. The Emperor prevented from seeing his experiments by the death of His Majesty's mother. Wishes to hear news of America and explanation of Arnold's treachery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Repaired the cases of Madeira and forwarded them to Passy; recommending their wine and furnishing prices.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Offers to provide the army with everything necessary in time of war, at a most reasonable figure.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating him on the recovery of his health. Will be glad to see the details of Arnold's conduct; blames Congress and court-martials for inflicting slight punishment on criminals and then entrusting them with commands and employment; advises suing such knaves at common law; Arnold's case in point; the villain's bravery and baseness. Rumor of Gates obtaining an advantage over Cornwallis. The papers give out that M. Rochambeau has come to solicit more troops; the great need is for ships and money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing bills of exchange for the use of S[amuel] C[ooper] Johonnot which he begs Franklin to take charge of.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The King of Prussia's influence in bringing about Holland's agreement to an armed neutrality. Proper time to enter their claim relative to the vessel carried off at Saba. Desiring a detailed account of Arnold's treason.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses the extract which he made longer than Mr. Vaughan's in order that it might be easily understood in French; it will appear in the Journal de Paris after being read at the Academy; desires Franklin to make any changes in it he may deem advisable.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Gourlade not yet gone; return the three packets that they may be forwarded by an earlier opportunity; one of them for Mr. Jones.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing three letters for Henry Laurens, which were to have been forwarded to Amsterdam; has heard of Mr. Laurens's unfortunate capture, therefore sends them to Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledges Dr. Franklin's answer of November 14. Encloses three identical letters to Evangelical Lutheran Ministers at Philadelphia, and two letters from relatives of his, with request to forward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An account of the entire affair in regard to the loading of his vessel, the "Marquis de la Fayette"; blames Franklin's nephew, Mr. Williams, for his interference; encloses certain papers and begs that no time may be lost before coming to some arrangement; his interests suffer cruelly by such delays.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking that the bearer be given the petition to the Minister of the Marine and the Report of the Committee of the House of Commons. Desires a few lines of introduction to Franklin's friends at Versailles. Mr. Pecholier, whom he proposes in the petition as his associate, is in one of the first houses in London.
A.E. by Franklin setting forth M. Charretié's good character.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to know if an important and interesting packet sent to Franklin through another person, has been received.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. Acknowledge receipt of letter and request to know the subject of the packet, as many are received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served the United States from March, 1776 to July, 1780; his health obliged him to leave; encloses papers for certification to prove the truth of his statements.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards a little memoir, and desires Franklin to write his answers upon the margin; hopes his importunity may be pardoned on account of his sincere attachment to him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fresh difficulties started at Bordeaux; encloses copy of his letter [4 p., in French] to Messrs. Jauge and fils urging the necessity for the speedy departure of the "Marquis de la Fayette". Quantity of arms on board the "Mars".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Intends sending a courier to Nantes, who will return at the end of the week with the decision of the Arbitrators; believes it will be the same as that of Bordeaux.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: De Tousard, Lt Col Louis. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes to return to the United States where he has already fought through two campaigns and been seriously wounded; has chosen as his intermediary, M. de Chaumont, who knows his zeal for the great cause.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Lafayette, Marie Joseph Paul Yves, marquis de, 1757-1834

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The enemy have gone into winter quarters and by their position effectually cover the State of New Jersey; their refusal to fight; have improved every occasion of striking at them on a smaller scale. Major [Benjamin] Tallmadge's brilliant dash into Long Island and his safe return with four officers and fifty privates prisoners. Letter from Gen. Gates reports a new advantage obtained in South Carolina by Sumter; the enemy do not possess a single post east of Georgetown or north of Camden. British corps under Gen. Leslie have abandoned hope of a junction by land with Cornwallis; every one of their plans in this campaign defeated. The states exerting themselves in order that an army may soon take the field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sailed in the "Alliance" a year before; Capt. Jones put him in command of a Dutch prize with orders to proceed to Philadelphia; taken prisoner by the English and after many vicissitudes, made his escape; is penniless; begs for assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the request of a correspondent, they forward the enclosed letter.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Summoned by M. de Montaudouin to answer his interrogatories; thinks this second decision will be doubly in his favor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No answer to be made to Sir Joseph Yorke's insolent memoir; hears that he is about to present a second; its contents. Reasons why his stay in Amsterdam is advisable. Desires to take the oath of allegiance to the United States.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wishes Franklin's opinion as regards Mr. Samuel Wharton's probity and punctuality in business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses letters brought with him from London; sorry for unavoidable delay. Dr. Fothergill's intention of writing to Franklin by a private hand; his opinions of the present state of affairs. Proposes going to Boston and exercising his profession there; believes it is not so necessary for men to go to Europe in order to cure the diseases of their next door neighbor; learnt many things during his stay with Dr. Fothergill. Read with interest the French medical work Franklin gave him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The "Ariel" will be under sail at daybreak; neither Mr. Gourlade nor M. de La Grave have yet appeared; enloses receipt for arms; is taking ninety days' provisions. Had [Arthur] Lee and his cabal in the "Alliance" been in Heaven, the "Ariel," would have been no additional expense, and,with the "Alliance", would have carried the greatest part of the winter clothing for our army. Not surprised at the few desertions; encloses list of the present crew.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: De Tousard, Lt. Col. Louis. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gives his address.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses the papers relative to the Portuguese prize, which the Captain desires to have legalized; encloses memoir in case it be thought necessary to forward it to Congress.
(In French).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing the arrival of the cutter "Franklin"; a most beautiful vessel. No news of Capt. Courter, but M. Salomes has found an excellent substiute, who will forward his papers at once, as they are anxious to sail.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrived at Passy to find that Franklin had left for Versailles. Two enclosures; one, a copy in French of a letter from M. Necker to M. Grand (2p., in French) concerning a letter of credit; the other, from Mr. Franklin to M. Grand (1p.) concerning money matters.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resolution that the Minister at United States, at St. Petersburg, be furnished with letters of credit upon the Minister at Versailles to the amount of fifteen hundred pounds.
(Copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His son promoted to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel; eager to show his gratitude and appreciation; offers his services to the United States even at his advanced age.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: While in London, Mr. Temple confided to his care a letter of introduction to Franklin for the Princess Descau [Daschkow] whom he said was a favorite of the Empress; she had insisted on having such a letter and it was not until that day he had discovered from the Prince of Gallitzin where she was, and added in consequence a few lines of apology for Mr. Temple and himself. Left Mr. Digges in a disagreeable situation owing to Mr. Trumbull's being taken up.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seditious libels circulated by the English party. Enclosing copy of a certificate [1 p.] signed by Messrs. Adams and Searle, stating that he took the oath of allegiance to the United States; is now provided with an answer to many embarrassing questions.
(In French.)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1 C[harles] G[uillaume] F[rederic] Dumas, after having taken the Oath of Allegiance to the United States, appears to have anglicised his name and signed himself thereafter C[harles] W[illiam] F[rederic] Dumas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing papers relative to the prisoners taken by Capt. Babcock, and released on the conditions therein certified (3 p.).

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Walter Williams and Helenus Scott. Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have come to Paris to renew their request (XX, 50); desirous of obtaining a passage on a vessel of the King.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will not fail to pay his respects the following day.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Poulain de Ceintré, Henri-Louis Florimont. Near Angers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desires to serve in the army as an officer.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwards a letter from Mme. la Comtesse de Preysing to M. le Chevalier de la Luzerne.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prevented from answering Franklin's obliging letter by a severe attack of gout; describes the difference between his attack and a disease called strangury; remedies used for this latter. Instead of general wars, would like to see a College of Justice where the claims of sovereigns could be weighed and war only levied on those who refused submission. Advises the establishment in the United States of one general standard of weights and measures. Questions of oaths and affirmations. Singular that Massanchusetts should have framed one of the most liberal plans of Government since the beginning of the world. He and his friend Dr. Barclay have established a school in Yorkshire in order to provide a plain education for children not in affluent circumstances; its success so far. Hopes that his friend and relatives, Dr. Waterhouse, will teach in the future Massachusetts College of Medicine; as yet he is too young and inexperienced.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Affairs berween Holland and England; resolutions adopted by the former; departure of Sir Joseph Yorke for Antwerp; embargo declared in London on all Dutch vessels.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lines to Dr. Franklin on reading his works.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is the author of a work on the clearing of uncultivated lands; intended offering several copies to Congress and to the Academy; it has already been welcomed by the principal Sovereigns of Europe.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sailed in the "Boston," Capt. Tucker, with a promise of a share of the prize-money; taken prisoner and remained eighteen months in an English jail; is unable to Find Capt. Tucker; begs for his share of the money.
(In French.)
A.E. by Franklin. Has nothing to do with division of the "Bostons's" prize-money; advises writing to the Admirality in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served for six months on board the "Lexington" as cook and interpreter; desires his wages and his share of the prize-money.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notice of a public meeting of the Faculty of Medicine of the Collége de France as provided for in the will of M. Malouin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Annexes a copy (1p.) of a letter just received from Ostend, mentioning the receipt of the London Gazette, containing the King of England's manifesto against the Dutch.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: John de Neufville and Son. Amsterdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulating Franklin on the firm stand the Dutch Republic has taken in regard to the impudent demands of England; makes no doubt that they will soon be at an open rupture; hopes Holland's friendly feeling for America will turn to the advantage of both countries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has a letter from Mr. Adams and one from Mr. Dumas of an old date, as he left Amsterdam the first of the month. Will pay his respects as soon as he feels better. Trusts Franklin is relieved from the gout.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to let his servant take the trunks left at Passy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Recommending M. Petry, Secretary of the French army under Rochambeau. Asking letters of introduction for him to some of Franklin's friends in Newport or Providence, Rhode Island.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writes on behalf of the Comtesse Dillon, who wishes to know the safest way of sending her letters to her husband and friends in M. de Ternay's fleet.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending a pamphlet.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for the letters of introduction for M. Savari which Franklin had promised to send her.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is Director of the Seminary at Béziers and a member of several Academies. Sent to Franklin some time ago a memoir on a new means of preserving oneself from thunder and lightning. Would like to hear from Franklin what he thinks of it.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returns to Franklin by messenger the dog which came back to her house.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will be at Franklin's house at time appointed with the Comtesse de Rochambeau. All her friends at Passy, including Mme. De Tonnerre, would like to take tea with him to-morrow.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obliged to go to Paris on business. Requests Franklin to postpone his invitation to Sunday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is sorry Dr. Franklin cannot dine with them. Asks him if he could receive the Comtesse de Rochambeau and herself on Wednesday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dr. Franklin's neighbors have not seen him for a long time. Ask him to come and take tea with them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Dr. Franklin to come to see them and take tea. Mme, de Vaudois's illness has prevented them from going to see him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot go to Passy now to see Dr. Franklin. Invite him to come and take dinner with them. M. de Boulainvilliers in going to Spa for his Health.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has learned that Franklin's son was about to leave for America, having been appointed an Aide-de-camp to la Fayette. Expresses sorrow for Franklin at being onliged to part with his son.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquires about Franklin's health. Has expected to send him some notes, but was unable to write. Is far from being well herself.
(In French.)

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: Printed in Proc. Am. Phil. Soc., XL, 108.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is too ill yet to invite Franklin to tea. Will be glad to have a chat with him any time. Hopes she will enjoy better health during the approaching new year (1781). Only this hope prevents her from seeking death.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cannot dine with Franklin at Mme. Dutartre's house on Tuesday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Franklin to call for her in his carriage to take her to Mme. Dutartre's for dinner and back in the evening.
(In French.)
E. By W[illiam] T[emple] F[ranklin] that he had promised that Dr. Franklin would do as requested.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin and his grandson to dinner. They will have pleasure of hearing Mile. Cavachini and other excellent musicians from Italy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting Dr. Franklin's invitation to dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two notes Aug. 12, [1779]
Returning a copy of the "Courier de l"Europe" to Franklin and advising him that a case has arrived at M. de Chalut's, Fermiér-General addressed to Franklin. 2 Notes.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Giving their place of residence.
(In French)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter received from Comte d'Estaing, who had not yet dropped anchor at Brest; the Count injured by the force of the wind.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarding a dispatch from M. Dumas and a letter from M. Landais. He thinks only Jones to be able to say in America that he did not seek the command of the "Alliance"; desires to be employed in France.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Stating terms for the chartering the vessel "Le Breton" to carry merchandise for account of Congress.
(Copy.)
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of preceding and how payment was to be made for goods furnished by him to Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With reference to a bill paid by him for Mr. Robinson's account and which Mr. Williams of Nantes refused to acknowledge. Sends order for the cannon; notes by the Ambassador of Sweden and a note about "friend Jones."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Suggestions as to trade between Europe and America during the war and the use of paper money issued by Congress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requests Franklin to write to a Philadelphia merchant to procure a cargo of tobacco for a ship which he is sending to America under Capt. [Andrew] Patton with cargo of salt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commander of the vessel "la Sensible" which was three months at Boston; is intrusted with letters, packets and a small box for Franklin; his wish to pay his respects and deliver these in person; offers his services in case an opportunity should arise of his being useful to America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking for information concerning a cargo of brown sugar consigned to a merchant in Philadelphia; informed of its safe arrival in June 1780.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has had a vessel built and armed for privateering. Has strong reasons for desiring this vessel to sail under the American flag. Asks if Franklin can give him a commission.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to forward two letters for personal delivery to Henri Chevalier, 3d and Dock Sts., Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Autograph firm-signatures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Has intention to write a history of the American Revolution; applies to Franklin for assistance in obtaining data for his work.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is a native of Maryland; account of his capture by the English; his escape and subsequent capture and imprisonment by the French; begs Franklin to obtain his liberty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the business relations established between Mr. Adams and their company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the letter which be promised to forward to her friend [the Marquis de Chastellux].
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks him when he will take tea with her and when she should send the letter he is to forward to her friend.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends letter which Franklin promised to forward to her friend.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for further news about the arrival of her friend.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of bills drawn on B. Franklin by Govelade and Maylan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending him an extract of a letter from their friend in Madrid.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returns M. de Vergennes's letter to Franklin. Thinks 500,000 francs insufficient for Franklin's needs for January and February, considering the drafts to be met, etc. Estimate furnished to M. de Vergennes of money required by Franklin amounted in all to five millions.
(In French. Press copy.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deputed by M. Girardot to invite Franklin to dine with him Friday or Saturday in company with Mr. Paul Jones.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laying before Franklin his plan for increasing their credit.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the acceptance of Messrs. Gourlade and Moylan's draft.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to put off coming to tea till another day, owing to M. Grand's indisposition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making an appointment to wait upon Franklin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Must have that day the passport. Involved by him in a position to which death is preferable; sufficient guarantee in his possession to obtain the necessary loan; will wait upon him with securities amounting to more than his demand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deputed by Mme. la Marquise de Rochambeau to request any news from America relative to her son and M. de Ternay.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served as second lieutenant on board an American privateer; his wounds; captured by the English and subsequent sufferings; applies for redress.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Is sending his nephew to America to study commerce and learn the English language; begs Franklin to give him letters to Philadelphia and Boston.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invites him to dinner to meet M. Magellan and some members of the Academy.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending six bottles of beer as a gift from Mr. Magellan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends the last memoir by Dr. Ingen Housz.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends copy of translation with corrections agreed upon. Thinks it would be well to suppress the passages which he has enclosed in brackets.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asks for a copy of the captured letters of General Clinton, for the Russian Ambassador.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquring if he has received word of the arrival of M. de Rochambeau in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reminding Franklin of Count de Maillebois's invitation to dinner.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends letter from M. Destouches. Hopes that his dialogues with the gout are over.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Prat, Jules Comte Julius de Montfort de

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encloses a letter he has received from a woman (3 p.) exposing him as an impostor masquerading under an assumed name and threatening to tell Franklin.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desiring information of Lieutenant-Colonel Bedaulx; rumor of his death.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will wait on Messrs. Franklin to-morrow; but Mme. Helvétius will not be of the party, as her brother-in-law has just died.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hoping that Franklin can dine with his wife and himself on February 7th; his nephew, the Marquis de la Fayette, and his son, the Vicomte de Noailles will share the pleasure.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inviting Franklin to dine with them.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commodore Jone's arrival at Corunna; the English not nearly as insolent to him as to the Dutch. Account of many American gentlemen who escaped from English prisons; efforts made to obtain for some of them a passage home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advice that they have endorsed certain bills to Sir John Lambert.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting his invitation.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Abbè Guillaume - Thomas Francas ; Raynal, Abbè

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting Franklin to return his books and papers in order that he may publish his work on America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the dedication to Franklin of his legislative work.
(In French. In duplicate.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning the model of a gun-carriage which Franklin promised to offer to the United States; desires to know their response.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to know if the eclipse of the sun was observed in New York or New Cambridge.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Shipped in May, 1778, as a volunteer on the American frigate "Boston," Capt. Tucker. Was taken prisoner by the British cruiser "Porcupine" while on an English vessel seized by the "Boston." Remained two years in prison in England. Claims wages due him and his share of prize-money.
A.E. by Franklin. His claim should be made to the proper authorities in America where the "Boston" was fitted out. Advises him to send his claim and proofs to the Consul for France at Philadelphia.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hoped to present to Franklin, in person, his book entitled L'Art d'Essayer l' or et l'Argennt; instead has the honor of sending it by M. François Steinsky, Professor of Physics at Prague.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sending Franklin a book by one of his friends who greatly desires to see him.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Understands that Franklin visited M. Leschevin's collection of minerals at Versailles; gives it high praise.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Announcing his arrival in Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his invitation for dinner on Sunday; prefers to come on a day when he can see him alone.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Teissier de la Tour and Guiliet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning his arrest.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends certified copy of Resolution of Congress of December 8, 1780, in reference to the issue of setts of exchange in place of those lost. Notification of issue of same.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Turgot, Etienne-François, marquis (brother of baron). Paris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking letters of recommendation on behalf of a young merchant, M. de Roulhac, and a young engineer, M. Menedrieu de Barci, both of whom are in America.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accepting with pleasure Franklin's invitation to dine with him on Sunday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking if he can call for him in his carriage to go to dine at M. de Malesherbes's and if Mr. Jones will come also.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About seeing M. de Maillebois and about a certain letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to a letter sent to Franklin.
(In French.)

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Claude Henri Watelet and Mme. Lecomte

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanking him and his grandson for their visit and inquiring about their health.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deputed by the Duke de Nivernois to ask his good offices on behalf of the person mentioned in the enlosed note.
(In French.)
A. E. by Franklin. Directs an answer in the affirmative.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concerning a bill of exchange to be given M. de Chaumont by Franklin. Impatient to hear of the ship, the "Marquis de la Fayette," having quitted Bordeaux.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of the elections, received in a letter from his father-in-law [William Alexander].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Begging Franklin to purchase a specimen of her work, a portfolio, for the sum of two louis.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting an answer of some kind to her former letter, or the return of the portfolio.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledging his kindness; desires the certificate sent Franklin by the Prussian Ambassador; without it, cannot go to Holland.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sends German translation of Franklin's works. Wishes to know the titles of any other work written by him in order to have them added to these three volumes. The quarto book is from H: H. the Prince of Furstenberg, who has brought together here into a philosophical and historical society some learned men of this captial.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Warning him against entrusting the affairs of M. Chaffert to De Baumont. Says the latter is a swindler and has been in prison several times. The Public Prosecutor of the Chatelet district could tell all about him.
(In French.)
A.E. "Anonymous letter written with the left hand to avoid detection."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Highway robbers took the few francs he had; asks Franklin's assistance.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to a package of letters written by a self-styled prophet and miracle-worker and addressed to Congress and Washington.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the war between France and England and the reverses sustained by the English fleets. Reflection on current events of the war by an old man of eighty.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two American vessels having arrived at Bilbao, announce the capture, in Chesapeake Bay, of the "Romulus" by M. [Jean Le Gardeus] de Tilly, commander of "L'Eveille."
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to dine with M. Turgot and Baron d'Helbach at Franklin's house on Friday.
(In French.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Requesting him to let M. Turgot know if the dinner will take place next day.
(In French.)
